Basic to this system is a headquarters staff,
probably located in Washington, D. C.
(a) to provide direction and coordination
for the overall system
(b) to furnish special regular national
reporting of Congress, The Supreme Court, Department
of Defense, and so forth, and
(c) to produce and package one or more of
the major program blocks.
The key stations would be responsible for feeding
specific segments, features, talks, and certain time
blocks. Budget would be provided for permanent proÂ¬
ducing, personnel and for expenses necessary to produce
these segments and to commission talks and commentaries
by journalists, authorities, and academicians.
Additional originations and program contributions
would be drawn from the basic affiliates and paid for
by the system.
3) Production Techniques; The director of the
system and his production staff would be responsible for
creating the best possible consistent "sound". Styles
of presentation, quality of announcing, special audio
effects, and so forth would be required of all the key
members of the system so as to achieve the required
"national" identification. Satire, humor, musical
jingles, audience telephone participation are among the
many techniques of production to be employed and tested,
modes of aural communication and expression are to be
considered.
4) Program Distribution: Talk programming would
be distributed by AT&T circuits live for immediate
presentation over the key stations. (Tape delay for
time zones might be employed where and when needed.)
